Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The environmental stress on the climate system of our planet rapidly increases, creating novel societal problems too complex to be successfully tackled by traditional scientific approaches. This workshop seeks to address problems for societies created by changes in the regional hydrological cycle as a consequence of ongoing glacier and climate change. Its goals are to (i) review the sensitivity of glaciers to climate change on a near-global scale, (ii) to identify key regions on earth where the urge and potential for a cross-cutting projects are highest, and (iii) design strategies to work towards adaption and mitigation strategies.

Broader Impacts: This workshop is to our knowledge unique in including leading experts from disciplines such as glacial geology, glaciology, climatology, hydrology, anthropology, human ecology, and international affairs, providing a forum to create modern approaches to tackle burning environmental problems. The workshop includes young female scientists from the US and Europe and will foster the communication and cooperation between social and natural sciences. Beyond, it will be an excellent opportunity for Columbia University/Lamont students to gain insight in modern environmental sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The climate stress on the environmental system of our planet rapidly increases, creating novel societal problems too complex to be successfully tackled by traditional scientific approaches. The goal of this workshop was to address problems for societies created by changes in the regional hydrological cycle as a consequence of ongoing glacier and climate change. Specific topics incuded (i) to review the sensitivity of glaciers to climate change on a near-global scale, (ii) to identifiy key regions on earth where the urge and potential for a cross-cuting projects are highest, and (iii) design strategies to work towards adaption and mitigation strategies.

This workshop held November 11-13, 2009 at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory brought together leading experts cross-cutting disciplines such as glacial geology, glaciology, climatology, hydrology, anthropology, human ecology, and international affairs, providing a forum to create modern approaches to tackle burning environmental problems. The workshop included young female scientists from the US and Europe and fosteredhe communication and cooperation between social and natural sciences.

The most important outcome of the workshop was that the hydrological changes in Central Asia and the tropical Andes were identified as key problem to tackle. The approach designed at the workshop to evaluate the dynamics of these changes and their major impacts on environment and society, should be based on quantitative methods to measure the past and modern rate of glacier change. This foundation allows for more reliable prediction of future glacier change, in turn helping the IPCZ in one of the most criticized aspects. Hydrological expertise is needed to transform the upstream glacier changes to downstream water availability and flood hazard assessements. This approach includes design of stream-flow modulation to increase the hydropower efficiency, and is thus directly linked to economic issues. Finally, social scientists add assessments of the vulnerability of societies and cultural communities facing the dramatic environmental changes.
